title: Thursday, 20th April, 2017
bodyHTML:
10:59 am
PM10:59am

Morning

PM11:00am

I've got a bit of Japanese seasoning in my eye, so you'll have to give me a minute

PM11:00am

Actually, you can have a minute of Trump

11:00 am
PM11:00am

https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/854749300114546688

PM11:01am

You know we only share Trump tweets now when they are truly extraordinary

PM11:01am

If you watch that with the sound off it's like a take on Kim Jong-Un

11:01 am
PM11:01am

With the volume on it's just laugh out loud stupid

PM11:02am

But let's press on with market stuff

PM11:02am

US market stuff

11:02 am
PM11:02am

These letters -- Kleinfeld / Elliott

PM11:02am

Wow

PM11:02am

Go here: http://newarconic....-kleinfeld-letter/

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Read from the bottom up

PM11:03am

Actually, let me get a screen grad to save you clicking

PM11:03am

11:03 am
PM11:03am

If yo ucan't read that, just click the link above

PM11:04am

Cost Kleinfeld his job, of course.

PM11:04am

Extraordinary, tho

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Btw, that site is the Elliott proxy site -- not Arconic

BE11:04am

Okay, here's my response to reading the above: Klaus was naive and Elliott were Elliott.

BE11:05am

Klaus was naive because he seemed to have forgotten, or disregarded, that Elliott is Elliott. They'll use anything against you as leverage if there's a dime in it.

11:05 am
PM11:06am

True

PM11:06am

But the letter reads drunk -- and yet it was couriered round. ie he had time to sober up

BE11:06am

Dunno.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

I'd quite like to live in a world where you can send your bette noir a heavily sarcastic letter about someone falling into a fountain during a football tournament in 2006 and not have it considered an act of war by the other side.

BE11:07am

Frankly, it's Elliott that looks bad here. And, one might argue, hypocritical.

BE11:07am

.... given ........ other .................... events.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Why hypocritical?

BE11:07am

Let's leave that one hanging I think.

PM11:08am

Related to that stuff i mentioned yesterday, is suspect...

11:08 am
BE11:08am

But Elliott won't care at all, because there's a dime in it. They're the unacceptable, humourless, shark-eyed face of modern activist capital.

BE11:08am

Doing nothing for humanity other than extracting dimes for their clients.

PM11:08am

They need a proof reader

11:08 am
PM11:08am

I know we can't talk on such stuff

BE11:08am

You applying?

PM11:08am

But noticed a literal on their proxy site

11:08 am
PM11:09am

Arconic operates a world-class collection of assets that it managed properly, with prudent reinvestment of capital, should produce substantial returns for its shareholder owners. Unfortunately, despite these valuable assets, considerable shareholder value has been destroyed over the past decade under the watch of current management.

PM11:09am

Should be 'if' rather 'it' in the first line.

PM11:09am

Invoice in the post

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Clear indication of ineptitude. We should mount a proxy battle against Elliott.

BE11:10am

They're destroying shareholder value by their inability to spell.

BE11:10am

Anyway .... should we move on?

11:10 am
PM11:10am

guess so

undefined
PM11:10am

Footsie flat again

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Sterling now completely de-krona-ed

BE11:11am

Exciting, huh.

PM11:11am

Wel,, 1.2822 -- come off a bit in the last hour

11:11 am
PM11:11am

There's loads of trading statements out

PM11:11am

Do we focus on those?

BE11:12am

Depending on demand ... I mean, it's a Thursday and there's a lot of news out there, but none of it hugely interesting.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Leading us down we have Debenhams, which as good a place to start as any.

Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 52.30, down 3 (-5.42%), High: 55.60, Low: 52.05, Volume: 4.14m
BE11:12am

Short term pain, long term ........... well, who knows?

11:12 am
PM11:12am

http://www.investe...1704200700077853C/

PM11:13am

Debenhams Redesigned

BE11:13am

We're getting more store closures under new CEO Sergio Bucher, in what must be the seventh strategy rejig in as many years.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Focus on digital.

PM11:13am

But this could be seismic

PM11:14am

They are promising to answer the question of what Debenhams is for

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Closing 10 stores out of 176 doesn't sound seismic.

PM11:14am

Objective to define clearly what Debenhams stands for

BE11:14am

Well, good. That's something.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

I've noticed, incidentally, that Debenhams' solution to having too much floorspace is to put in food concessions .....

PM11:15am

Food!?!!?

BE11:15am

Yup .... the Westfield one has a Franco Manca, an Ed's Easy Diner, a Costa and a cake shop.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Because that, apparently, is a better use of space than selling actual products.

BE11:16am

What Debenhams seems to be for is to make mini-malls, inside other malls ....

PM11:17am

They'll be scribbling that down at Debs HQ Bryce

11:17 am
BE11:17am

......... where you can buy a small range of own-brand products with a very large number of labels attached, somewhat arbitrarily.

BE11:17am

Then have a pizza.

PM11:17am

That too

11:17 am
BE11:18am

You can do Elliott sub-editing, I'll do the Debenhams strategy. We have our post-journalism plans sorted.

PM11:18am

Thumbs up

BE11:18am

Anyway, sellside. Saying it's inline, sounds sensible, but it's still Debenhams.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Stifel!

BE11:18am

Debenhams’ new strategy aims to capitalise on smartphone, social media and “experiences” secular growth trends to make Debenhams a “Social Shopping” leader. To this end, capex is rising by c.£20m per annum to FY20, implying stable, rather than falling, net debt. The strategy is in tune with prevailing retail realities and reflects Debenhams’ store portfolio constraints. The key test will be in execution, particularly in IT, digital marketing and logistics.

BE11:19am

3% profit beat at interim level: Interim PBT was £87.8m, 2.7% ahead of expectations on GTV 2.9% ahead to £1.677m. Gross margins were down 30bps as expected (reduced markdowns partially offsetting sales mix impacts) implying a better than expected operating costs performance. The dividend is maintained at 1.025p as expected and the pension scheme is £47m in surplus.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

(Would you go to Debenhams for "experiences"? That suggestion sends my mind in all sorts of unfortunate directions.)

BE11:19am

Debenhams Redesigned: Destination, Digital and Different: As we highlighted in our results preview two weeks ago, most of Debenhams’ closest competitors have undergone strategic reviews and we expected similar conclusions. Today’s press release gives a clearer indication as to why Sergio Bucher (Amazon, Inditex, Puma) was appointed CEO, combining his online and offline retail experience to make Debenhams a “Social Shopping” leader. Expected to take three years to implement, the new strategy aims to exploit secular smartphone, social media and “experience” consumer trends to drive footfall into the stores, leveraging Debenhams’ strengths in beauty, accessories and food and drink. With limited scope to reduce the store footprint, management plans to use underperforming retail space to enhance the overall shopping/leisure experience. The strategy will require Debenhams to invest in mobile technology and digital marketing to become a retail sector social media leader.

BE11:20am

Targeting efficiency gains: Alongside the growth strategy above, Debenhams is aiming to improve efficiency by investing selectively in the store estate, potentially closing 10 stores in the next five years and simplifying the business by investing in IT to improve warehouse automation and in-store replenishment.

Financial implications: We suspected that management might sacrifice its debt reduction and dividend cover targets in order to increase investment and this has proved to be the case. Over the next 3 years capex rises c.£20-25m pa to around £150m, implying broadly neutral net cash flow, a maintained dividend and a 2x dividend cover target. Efficiency plans may result in a £50m exceptional charge over the next 3 years, of which c.50% will be in cash.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Management: The statement details no changes to the main executive board although we believe operating management will be reinforced to enhance the group’s IT and logistics capability.

Forecasts: The group has updated guidance. FY17 PBT expectations are expected to remain around £103m PBT with the H1 beat being offset by slightly more cautious gross margin and cost assumptions. While we digest the implications of the strategy review, we are maintaining FY18 estimates at our low end £88m PBT (5.8p EPS), implying a c.25% sector P/E discount.

BE11:20am

..... And Peel Hunt.

BE11:20am

Debenhams’ H1 PBT came in broadly in line with expectations,
although downside pressure from costs and margins means
downgrades to full-year expectations and future years. The
strategy is as expected; Debenhams needs a fairly radical
overhaul in order to be relevant to consumers and to drive sales.
On paper, this is fairly difficult to bring to life with conviction,
ultimately it’s all about execution and the market will remain
wholly sceptical until there is clear evidence of the changes
taking hold. Until then, the shares are likely to follow the
numbers, with significant downgrades for future years as GP
remains flat, steadily eroded by relentless cost growth.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Social Shopping; delivering the dream. The strategy is based around the heading of “Social Shopping”. There’s nothing here to create a surprise and indeed, there is no miracle solution. Management needs to make Debenhams more relevant to consumers in order to generate sales growth. All of the initiatives make clear sense on paper, equally we expect the market to remain sceptical until management can demonstrate progress. The details of the strategy will see upgraded mobile capability, a revamped Designers at Debs offer, easier to shop stores, fewer options, faster replenishment, a step up in the food & drink offer and more compelling in-store events. Essentially this is about creating a more compelling, easier to shop offer, building on the strength of health, beauty and gifting, and providing more leisure and services. Up to 10 stores may close over five years and the warehouse and distribution function will continue to be automated and modernised, with a main DC to close. Capex increases by £100m over three years, exceptional costs of £50m, half of which is cash.

BE11:21am

Now it’s time for the retail detail. Retail is detail – if Debenhams can provide a compelling offer, in an inspirational environment, management will be able to return the business to sales growth. Currently the stores look tired, as does much of the offer. New CEO Sergio Bucher will talk passionately about change and delivery, but few will take the leap of faith ahead of clear evidence of performance. Until then, the shares will struggle to keep a double-digit PER.

BE11:22am

"if Debenhams can provide a compelling offer, in an inspirational environment ....." Okay, I'm going to suggest not.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

(@Blue horseshoe: no it's not.)

undefined

So, this Advancedpierre thing mentioned on the right.

11:23 am

Packaged food, has a relationship with Kraft-Heinz, close competitor was just bought out ......

BE11:24am

BE11:24am

But look at the volume yesterday. Seven times the average.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

(Greencore - Peacock Foods was the peer being bought out. That was the name I was trying to remember.)

BE11:25am

It's another of these stories -- like Gemalto, funnily enough -- that everyone seems to have heard.

BE11:26am

Doesn't mean they're wrong, but added to yesterday's volume spike it's a good reason for caution, which is what we're showing here.

11:26 am
undefined
PM11:26am

Unilever top of the Footsie gainers

PM11:27am

But there's not much here that wasn't flagged, surely

11:26 am
PM11:27am

Given the news flow

PM11:27am

And your work Bryce

PM11:27am

Q1 figs here http://www.investe...1704200700107918C/

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Yeah, that was my impression. They've had an update per week for about three months.

PM11:28am

Bump to the divi -- was that flagged? Not sure

PM10:59am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:29 am
BE11:29am

The overarching theme is that the business is operating in a tough world but is being run sensibly. Have to say, Unilever's PR's been very good to get that message across.

PM11:29am

This is true

BE11:29am

RBC incoming.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Q1 organic sales growth of 2.9% comfortably beat the company compiled consensus of 2.0% with both volume (-0.1%) and price (+3.0%) exceeding consensus expectations of -0.5% and +2.5% respectively. As with Nestlé, India performed well, while Brazil struggled. European and North American markets both declined in the quarter. It’s notable that the personal care division turned in organic growth of 3.1% … we had been concerned following L'Oréal’s uninspiring 1.4% organic growth from its consumer division in Q1. Our concern was unfounded.

BE11:30am

And Liberum, off the call.

BE11:30am

Unilever hosted a balanced 1Q’16 call highlighting that market growth remains sluggish at c.2% with slightly negative volumes. One less trading day, a later Easter and a tough comp hurt 1Q’17 growth although Unilever took share in most markets. Brazil remains particularly challenging with LfL sales falling 10% impacted by retailer destocking although the market improved falling only 5-6% versus -10% in 4Q. Developed markets remain deflationary and promotional with the U.S. market contracting 1% in 1Q. Despite the weak market context, Unilever flagged rising optimism for improved growth prospects calling out stabilizing trends in LatAm and Asia pricing, rising commodity prices and easier comps in 2H. The group reiterated the new strategic targets issued two weeks ago and noted that FX is shifting to a tailwind adding 3-4% to EPS in 2017.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

There's a lot of this. I'll cut to the conclusion.

BE11:31am

We rate Unilever HOLD with a €45 GBp 3,870 target price following Kraft Heinz’ aborted bid. Our prior stance (SELL) was predicated on weak organic sales growth, slow margin growth, a lazy balance sheet and an expensive valuation. Post bid, the Unilever organization appears galvanized to take more urgent steps to unlock value across the group. A thorough business review resulted in a plan to lift margins, drive capital efficiency and increase shareholder returns. In our view, the risk reward outlook for the shares is now more balanced. However, with Unilever shares up 21% since the bid we see a lot of market expectation baked into the group's share price.

BE11:31am

Unilever currently trades on a cal’17E PE of 23.1x vs. a 10yr average of 16.0x and at a 5% premium to Consumer Staples. This appears fairly valued given the potential for faster margin expansion and potential cash usage towards further buybacks and/or major M&A. The shares offer a cal’17E dividend yield of 3.0%

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Twenty-three times!

BE11:32am

For a soap and ice cream conglomerate doing mediocre growth. It's odd how investment fashions change.

undefined
11:32 am
PM11:33am

Sky's pretty much unmoved on the latest statement

PM11:33am

http://www.investe...1704200700127951C/

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 983.00, up 1 (+0.10%), High: 985.00, Low: 980.00, Volume: 2.37m
11:33 am
PM11:33am

What's teh Murdoch bid again?

PM11:33am

PM11:34am

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Yup. And the likelihood of the bid's all that matters, of course. In its avsence I'd assume these results would be seen as rather negative.

PM11:34am

Ive got some Polo Tang

PM11:34am

He thinks they're doing ok

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Revenues and operating profit on track
Sky produced a surprisingly full set of Q3 results (as opposed to a revenue/trading statement similar to Q1). Revenues for 9m grew +5% on an underlying basis to £9,641m (UBSe +5% to £9,636m) with adj. operating profit for 9m falling -11% underlying to £1,013m (UBSe -10% to £1,021m). Profitability is being impacted by the step up in EPL costs (+£630m for the FY) and launch costs relating to Sky Mobile (£70m for the FY), but this is largely being offset by cost savings and good revenue growth. We would not expect any changes to consensus numbers for FY-17 that imply EBITA of c£1.45bn/EPS of 58p and Sky noted they were “on track for the full year”

PM11:35am

Geographic breakdown as expected although UK net adds light
By geography, revenue growth and adj. operating profit was broadly in-line (UK +4% underlying revenue growth for 9m, Germany +10%, Italy +4% excluding the one-off from Olympics). In terms of net adds, UK was light at +40k (UBSe +70k) potentially due to promotional activity in the broadband market impacting stand-alone broadband net adds, Germany was solid at +73k (UBSe +70k) and Italy was -7k (UBSe +5k). Sky noted that churn levels for the UK in Q3 were stable vs Q2 (implying 11.6%) but they expected this to improve in the coming quarters.

PM11:35am

Tang of UBS, of course

11:35 am
BE11:35am

So we have revenue growth slowing quite a bit .........

BE11:36am

... we have operating profit down 11% due to the cost of football matches fewer and fewer people are actually watching.

BE11:36am

(Or paying to watch, perhaps, though there are any number of factors to viewing figures that we've discussed ad nauseum.)

11:37 am
BE11:37am

The bear scenario of football inflation and falling subs seems to be playing out. It's lucky Murdoch's there as a backstop.

PM11:38am

And BT

BE11:38am

Well, yes. Here's Shore, which downgraded to "hold" halfway through yesterday.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Not entirely sure why. It looked a little like they were checking their ratings pre results and remembered they were still buyers of a stock that's now the very definition of dead money.

BE11:39am

We are positive on Sky’s record of growth, innovation and customer focus and forecast solid three-year aggregate EPS and DPS growth of 25% and 19%, respectively. However, we viewed the group’s stock as fairly valued prior to Dec’s bid given concerns over competitive developments, Brexit and the longer-term sustainability of its subscription-based model. We regard Fox’s 1075p cash offer (FY17F and FY18F P/E, and DY ratios of 18.4x 3.3% and 15.6x 3.5% respectively) as credible, if undoubtedly opportunist, although we were disappointed by the failure of the directors charged with representing external investors to secure an improved price for a unique asset in a consolidating market. We expect the offer to succeed, but envisage a protracted process and see better value elsewhere in the sector in the Media in the meantime. We retain our Hold recommendation.

undefined
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Brief mention of Ashtead, since it's leading us down.

BE11:40am

United Rentals numbers overnight not good.

BE11:41am

Which usually sends Ashtead down -- even though the argument commonly made is that Ashtead's a smaller, more nimble company with an increasing market share an acre of growth ahead of it so United Rentals doing badly is usually good news for Ashtead.

11:41 am
Ashtead Group PLC (AHT:LSE): Last: 1,547, down 77 (-4.74%), High: 1,569, Low: 1,525, Volume: 941.84k
BE11:42am

Jefferies says this:

BE11:42am

Overnight Ashtead key peer, United Rentals reported 1.5% 1Q17 EBITDA miss ($591m vs $600m cons) but positive 2017 volume outlook: 17Q1 volumes rose 7% (up from +4.3% in 16Q4), due to improving end market demand (positive), but EBITDA margins fell 100bp Y/Y, with -1.4% 17Q1 rental rates (better than -1.8% in 16Q4, but not as good as hoped for!). URI FELL 6% in after-hours trading, despite reaffirmed 2017 outlook (& 5% 2017 EBITDA guidance raise from NES acquisition).
Jefferies believe there is intense competition between market leader United Rentals (11% share), rapidly growth #2 Ashtead (Sunbelt, 7% share), #3 Herc Rentals (3% share), now demerged from Hertz Car Hire and #5 Blueline Rentals (2% share) for large volume contracts (have been for years). 68% of URI business is key/national accounts (each over $100k pa revenue). By comparison; less than 30% of Ashtead business is similar key/national accounts, so have less exposure to this intensively competitive area.
We have spoken with both United Rentals and Ashtead management teams overnight. Ashtead current trading (volume & pricing) remains in-line with its prior guidance… do not see FY17/18 consensus estimates changes. However: As expected, Ashtead hit by negative read-across today.
Bottom Line: Despite improving US macro outlook (as evidenced by URI volume growth acceleration), we prudently retain unchanged Ashtead FY17 estimates: £780m PBT & 103.2p EPS (in-line with cons). Trading on CY17 6.4x EV/EBITDA & 14.8x P/E, (modest premium to rental peers reflecting faster growth & lower leverage) see any short term weakness as buying opportunity ahead of June 13 Ashtead FY17 Q4 results.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

And RBC says this.

BE11:42am

Whilst EPS of $1.63 was ahead of market's expectation of $1.55, EBITDA was c2% below consensus, which was driven by a 1.4% decline in rates (offsetting an encouraging 7% increase in volumes). However, underlying guidance has been maintained and it is encouraging to note the positive tones around the market outlook going into the key construction period (recent ABI data backs this up) and improving trends in its upstream oil and gas business (which should allay some of the oversupply concerns).

The shares were down some 5% after hours on this rate concern and Ashtead could see some pressure today. However, we would note that AHT has considerably stronger growth momentum (rental revenue +12% in Q3 at Sunbelt), continues to push up margins (despite rates in negative territory) and has much less exposure to oil and gas and no material exposure to Canada.

We next hear from the group on 13 June (Q4 and FY17) and expect a continued positive growth message alongside an announcement on a capital returns strategy – we believe there is an implied £1bn available to return if management remain comfortable with the cycle and therefore move towards the top end of its leverage guidance (2x). In our view, the shares continue to look good value on 12.6x CY18 PE and 5.5x EV/EBITDA for double-digit earnings and DPS growth. Any weakness today should be seen as a buying opportunity. We reiterate our Outperform.

BE11:43am

You can also, if you wish, watch Ashtead's CEO in conversation with Liberum.

http://www.liberum.com/videos/ashtead

This communication is for use only by a person or entity that qualifies as a "Professional Client" or "Eligible Counterparty" within the meaning of the FCA's rules.

BE11:49am

11:49 am
Man Group PLC (EMG:LSE): Last: 149.50, up 5.1 (+3.53%), High: 151.60, Low: 146.80, Volume: 7.90m
PM11:49am

http://www.investe...1704200700117923C/

BE11:49am

That's an ex-div 3.5% gain if I'm not mistaken.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

(Though that div would've been a lot bigger had they not chucked money away buying GLG ..... )

BE11:50am

Good news on inflows.

BE11:51am

$3bn in the first quarter

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Suggesting that when AHL does okay, it can actually actually attract new money.

BE11:52am

And we have the surplus capital line growing again, either for shareholder returns or more destructive acquisitions that fail to reduce its reliance on AHL.

BE11:53am

Who can we quote on this? Numis? Let's quote Numis.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

AuM at $88.7bn was 3.6% head of our $85.6bn forecast, principally driven by better than expected net inflows of $3.0bn (our est. $0.5bn). This positive flow surprise was principally driven by $1.4bn flows into GLG Long Only EM Debt strategies and a $1.4bn segregated Fund of Funds client. Management's outlook is simultaneously optimistic ("we continue to see near-term interest from clients") and cautious ("it is important to recognize that this is only one quarter and ... flows are likely to vary on a quarterly basis given the institutional nature of our business"). We expect to make overall small upgrades to our management fee profit forecasts given these better than expected Q1 results (partly offset by marking to market), but would not expect to significantly extrapolate one quarters worth of institutional flows.

BE11:53am

David McCann, of course.

BE11:53am

There remain many short to medium term uncertainties at Man, including inconsistent performance/performance fees, volatile flows and significant fee margin pressure. We think the short to medium term outlook for the current business is flattish, in terms of the direction of management fee profits. Upside could come from the surplus capital (c.15p/share currently plus the extent of future performance fee profits), which could be distributed and/or used for M&A (provided it is value accretive). We think M&A is more likely than capital returns. Overall we think the shares are broadly fairly valued, balancing the flattish outlook for the business (as measured by management fee profits), with the optionality of the surplus capital.

11:54 am
undefined
PM11:55am

We've largely avoid the French elections

PM11:55am

But they are this weekend, no?

11:55 am
PM11:55am

Think the French have a substantial black out period on polls

PM11:56am

And with this being so tight, the black out really has an effect

PM11:56am

Ive got a long Q&A from JPM which I will usual place for those interested

11:56 am
PM11:57am

Other than that

PM11:57am

Here's some Citi

PM11:57am

Highly uncertain outcome on Sunday
There are four candidates with a good chance of qualifying for the second and final round of the French Presidential elections, given the ±2.5% margin of error in polls. With 5 days to the first round on Sunday 23 April, Macron and Le Pen are the two candidates most likely to obtain the largest number of votes. But Fillon and Mélenchon are closing in, benefiting from recent positive momentum.

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Could undecided voters be a key factor?
Quite possibly, since polls frequently refer to around 30% of voters still hesitating between two or more candidates, suggesting that surprises remain possible once voters make their choice, perhaps at the last minute once behind the curtain in the polling booth. For the undecided, polls suggest that the most important criteria will be the programme (63%), rather than the personality of the candidate (20%) or their chance of winning (17%).

PM11:57am

What about certainty of choice?
Another element that needs to be incorporated is voters’ certainty of choice. This is useful to determine the minimum level of first-round votes. Le Pen still scores highly on this front, at around 19%, well ahead of Macron/Fillon at around 16-17% and Mélenchon on 13%. On this metric again, Fillon and Mélenchon are doing better, the former especially.

PM11:57am

What about participation?
Evidence from the polls suggests that the proportion of voters who are sure to vote is around 69% (and rising), with at least an extra 10% who think that they will but cannot say for certain. If the final turnout is low, this will likely favour sympathisers of Macron and Fillon, as well as the older generations, categories where polls suggest participation levels are the highest. Conversely, if the turnout is high, then the anti-establishment extremes are likely to do well.
What is in Mélenchon’s policy platform and how does it compare with others?
Investors (and French voters) are getting worried about a 'nightmare' scenario in which Le Pen faces Mélenchon on 7 May, leaving them with a hard choice between two anti-globalisation, anti-EU and pro-Russia candidates. Figure 3 presents a non-exhaustive list of key issues to compare Mélenchon and Le Pen and what their respective presidencies might look like in terms of political choices.

2nd-round hypotheses
Pollsters have been testing six different combinations, two of which would feature Mélenchon (vs. Le Pen and vs. Fillon) who would likely win these confrontations. In particular, a Le Pen vs. Mélenchon final would likely have far-reaching consequences for the country, as well as Europe at large.
Macron still the most likely to be elected President on 7 May
We reiterate our central scenario of a Macron win in the Presidential elections, on the basis that if he qualifies for the second round, his margin of victory against any of the other candidates looks very comfortable.
